none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. A. Alexander, May 30, 1887
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. A. Alexander, May 30, 1887
Box 3 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 3 Folder 4 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Canton Miss May 30th 1887

Dear McInnis:
Your letter has been on my table
for a week or two, awaiting an answer: Time to
indite which I have not had until this morning. I have
been occupied at literary work very closely, since the early
spring, & have done very little reading, not even He, She & It, save the newspapers &
what was necessary in preparing my discourses. The Hamilton –
Gambrell Trial on writ of Habeas Corpus, at Jackson, & the
daily proceedings of the General Assembly at St Louis, have
made voluminous demands on my time as well as
my eye sight; but both are now over. I have a thought of
going down to Jackson next Tuesday to hear the argument
in this famous case. for the argument has not yet been
made. For 10 days the people have talked about nothing else.
The Whiskey & Gambling elements sympathize with the accused
& are determined to whitewash, in their minds, the perpetrators.
The average citizen believes that there was a conspiracy –
My brother, now residing in Jackson, & partner of Judge Brame
is of the counsel for the State –
The General Assembly have been engaged in preliminary
skirmishing over the question of union with the Church South.
For the first time, it is now fairly before us. It is a more-
intricate question, & like many others, it has two sides, & will

The only tools at my disposal are some basic HTML tags - no fancy formatting, just the essentials. Then I scanned the image. I saw it was from Canton, Mississippi, dated May 30th, 1887, and addressed to "McInnis." The handwriting is cursive, a bit slanted, readable enough with some quirks. The content is about a busy schedule: literary work, not much reading other than newspapers and preparing discourses. There's a lot of focus on the "Hamilton-Gambrell Trial" and the "General Assembly" in St. Louis. I've got to watch for those little superscript "th"s and the ampersands, too! Next, I went through the document line by line, doing a first draft. I kept an eye out for a tricky insertion. I saw an interlineation "not even He, She & It". Based on the date, it could be a reference to a popular book or series of stories. I inserted that where it belonged. I also had to confirm that there was a historical context to the "Hamilton - Gambrell" name. Then, there were a few interesting elements I had to resolve. The prompt asked for "accuracy" which meant maintaining the intended final text after a correction, instead of showing the crossed-out text. And I had to think about preserving the flow. After all that, I double-checked everything: the spelling of every word, punctuation, and the capitalization of the proper nouns. I kept the original line breaks using the `
` tag. I had to pay close attention to the dashes, semicolons, and periods. And then, finally, I got the text, ready to go!

be well considered, I greatly fear that pressing the question now
will produce a breach in the church of a serious nature.
The North is crazy on union of any sort & with every
thing, since they "fought, bled & died," for union a quarter century
ago. They feel piqued in pride that they coerced us civilly but
that ecclesiastically we have preferred to walk apart. Church
union is not always a benefit. It may present a
united appearance to those that are without, while it brings
heterogeneous & antagonistic elements into contact in the
union. I do not believe Europe would be better
governed, or politically improved, if all the states &
nationalities of that quarter of the Earth, should be blended under
one rule. Homogeneity should be considered in every
organization, especially in the church. Presbyterians in
England, Scotland & Ireland maintain separate assemblies,
because of difference of tradition & blood. There should be
a like limitation here. I greatly fear that the idea
of bounding the church by national limits, means
destruction of harmony & the introduction of discord.

Bodies work best that are compact. The Northern Church want
to unite with the Southern Church, the Cumberland, the Dutch
Reformed & the Episcopalians. To this latter, I say - "God
save the mark". To the whole programme, I say call a
halt & go slow. The arguments for union are strong -
& may carry the majority. When the church is willing to
unite in a body, I will favor it. Much as my feelings are against

union at this time, my judgement, which I always reserve, in
important matters, may yet determine me to vote "aye". These arguments
are the interests of border churches & the growing unity of the
Country. To my mind a serious drawback is here, that the
north is less ready for union than the South. Southern Presbyterians
going north, unite with that Church. Northern Presbyterians hesitate to
unite with us. They distrust us & show prejudice. The negro question
is also a serious one.

It is possible that I will go up to the next Commencement at
Oxford. Powell thinks of going also. I would like to hear Frank Hurd
who is the orator. I hope you can be out & attend. If you can, it
will decide me to go. For I would be glad to perambulate about the
campus with you & hobnob for a day or two with the old professors.
I have not formed a plan for the summer yet. I have a
little thought of going to the University of Virginia & taking a
course in Hebrew of one month. This, if I should do it, would extend
from the latter part of July to the end of August.

I received your programme & rejoice to know that your
Institution is growing in excellence & popular favor, & that you
have succeeded in getting larger recognition at the hands of your
legislature. The Temperance agitation in your state will do good,
however your people may vote. It will educate the popular
conscience & open the eyes of the people to see what powerful
influence the liquor interests exert in politics, & have for
a long time exerted. If you could muzzle the rampant
women, the cause would have a better chance.
In public matters, their impulses are always right, God bless them, but

Line by line, I'll identify how to use the HTML tags (particularly `

but-They succeed often in alienating support from the prohibition
cause. Imported speakers, coming in as missionaries, have
the same effect. I have adopted the plan of not cooperating with
such tramps. They say extreme things & put us at home on the
defensive. The Local Option law is doing good in Mississippi &
I believe has a strong hold on the white voter. Counties that
voted no license are gratified with the experiment & if a
discrete policy is pursued, we can hold the ground we have
captured.

My Father is at the General Assembly in St.
Louis. He will attend the Commencement at Clarksville ere
he returns home. My second sister, Mary, has been in
delicate health this Spring, & has given us some uneasiness. She
is yet feeble. I am glad Henderson Alworth & family are
happily domiciled near you. Give my regards to them all.

C.M. Williamson & J.W. Coulter are candidates, & doubtless will
be chosen to the next Senate. It is reported that Ed. Mayes is booked
for the Supreme bench by Cleveland & Lamar. Such an appointment
would be highly applauded by me. The only drawback to Mayes, in the
eyes of Mississippians, is that he has never been active politically &
has made but few if any political speeches. I do not regard this
as a defect, though some attribute it to indifference. I attribute
it to his determination, as a lawyer, not to mix law & politics, a good
rule, for law is a jealous mistress & our best lawyers adopt it.
Politics may give one a name, but does not confer happiness.
Few retire from it gracefully. But I will close. Write soon & believe
me as ever your sincere friend

[Signature] W. A. Alexander

P.S. I appreciate the expressions of regard in your last letter & reciprocate [Margin: your fraternal feelings. Q. - It is always understood that I desire to be remembered to Mrs. Wood.]

Canton, Miss, May 30th, 1887

Dear McInnis:

Your letter has been on my table for a week or two, awaiting an answer: Time
to                 which I have not had until this morning. I have been occupied at literary
work very closely, since the early spring, & have done very little reading/[Insertion: Not even He, She & It]save the
newspapers & what was necessary in preparing my discourse. The Hamilton-Gambrell
trial on Writ of Habeas Corpus at Jackson, & the daily proceedings of the General
Assembly at St. Louis, have made voluminous demands on my time as well as my eye
sight, but both are now over. I have a thought of going down to Jackson next
Tuesday to hear the argument in this famous case - for the argument has not yet been
made. For 10 days the people have talked about nothing else. The Whiskey & gambling
elements sympathize with the accused & are determined to whitewash in their minds,
the perpetrators. The average citizen believes that there was a conspiracy. My
brother, now residing in Jackson & partner of Judge Brame is of the counsel for the
State.

The General Assembly have been engaged in preliminary skirmishing over the
question of union with the Church North. For the first time, it is now fairly
before us. It is a most intricate question, & like many others, it has two sides,
& will be well considered, I greatly fear that pressing the question now will
produce a breach in the church of a serious nature. The North is crazy on union
ever of any sort & xxxx with everything, since they "fought, bled & died," for
union a quarter century ago. They feel piqued in pride that they coerced us civilly
but that ecclesiastically, we have preferred to walk apart. Church union is not
always a benefit. It may present a united appearance to those that are without,
while it brings heterogeneous & antagonistic elements into contact in the union.
I do not believe Europe would be better governed, or politically improved, if all

**Thought Process: Transcribing a Typewritten Letter** Okay, so I've got this image, and my task is to transcribe the text. It looks like the tail end of a letter, judging by the salutation's continuation and the signature block. The text itself is clear and legible – thankfully, the typewriter's keys seem to have hit the paper with enough force to avoid any major ambiguity.
